title: Route announced for 2024 Ford RideLondon 100, confirmed until 2026
content:

Route announced for 2024 Ford RideLondon 100, confirmed until 2026

RideLondon – the UK’s biggest cycling event – has revealed the route for the Ford RideLondon-Essex 100, 60 and 30-mile challenge rides, to be used for the next three years.  

On Sunday 26th May 2024, the Ford RideLondon-Essex 100 will begin in central London and then head out through the London boroughs of Westminster, City of London, Tower Hamlets, Newham, Hackney, Waltham Forest and Redbridge, before going north towards Essex via Epping Forest and passing through towns such as Epping, Ongar and Great Dunmow.

Participants will ride on many of the same roads as the 2014 Tour de France peloton, taking in the sights of Chelmsford before returning to finish in London. The course is an evolved edition of the one used for the first two editions of Ford RideLondon-Essex, and will likely begin on London’s Embankment and finish on Tower Bridge, although that has still to be confirmed. 

An estimated 25,000 people will take part in the 2024 Ford RideLondon-Essex events while supporting thousands of charities – the rides have raised over £85million since the first edition in 2013. 

Cyclist magazine is proud to be the media partner for the Ford RideLondon events. Entries are available on a first-come, first-served basis. General entry for the 2024 Ford RideLondon-Essex 100 is £99 while the limited number of VIP entries costs £275, and you can sign up now.  

Entries for the Ford RideLondon-Essex 60 will open in November and entries for the 30-mile ride will open in the new year.  

The Essex rides are held on car-free roads and are part of a wider festival of cycling established by the Mayor of London in 2013 after the Olympics. There is also the RideLondon FreeCycle, which allows anyone to ride a route around some of the capital’s major sights on car-free roads, and the women’s pro race, The RideLondon Classique. 

The RideLondon Classique is held on the same Bank Holiday weekend as the Ford RideLondon mass-participation events and is a three-stage Women’s WorldTour race hosting some of the best professional riders from around the world. Last year, Charlotte Kool (Team DSM) won two stages, winning the overall by 11 seconds ahead of Canyon-Sram’s Chloe Dygert.
